comments:
Eclipse build: I20061205-1200

java version "1.4.2"
Java(TM) 2 Runtime Environment, Standard Edition (build 1.4.2)
Classic VM (build 1.4.2, J2RE 1.4.2 IBM Windows 32 build cn142-20050609 (JIT enabled: jitc))

I have a large self-hosting workspace that has most of Equinox+Platform as source plugins.  On every startup, a full rebuild happens, and I end up with compile errors on any reference to XML APIs (javax.xml.* and org.xml.*).  In the project properties, I see an access restriction has been created on xml.jar on the JRE classpath container. If I manually remove this access restriction, then all errors go away after a complete rebuild.

Marking critical because two complete rebuilds on each startup is a killer.

I have tried reproducing with a simple workspace containing only a couple of plugins, but no luck yet. Michael V has also seen this.

In case it's useful, here are the three access restrictions I am seeing on all the JARs on my JRE classpath container:

Accessible: java/**
Accessible: javax/microedition/io/*
Forbidden: **/*

I tried creating a new workspace, and exporting both platform-core and platform-ui modules from CVS. This is roughly the same set of projects that I have in my workspace, but it didn't reproduce the failure.  If there's anything else you want me to try, let me know.

I tried creating a new workspace, and exporting both platform-core and platform-ui modules from CVS. This is roughly the same set of projects that I have in my workspace, but it didn't reproduce the failure.  If there's anything else you want me to try, let me know.

Looks like you are getting bound to the foundation 1.0 profile. Do you have a j9 launching plug-in in your host (i.e. running the host with a J9 launching plug-in)?

No J9 plugin, no pure J9 VM installed. I have various VMs in the list of installed JREs (IBM/Sun 1.3/1.4/1.5), but no pure J9 VMs. In the EE prefernence page, I have my IBM 1.4.2 VM checked off as the preferred runtime for foundation 1.0, J2SE 1.3, and J2SE 1.4. I tried to mimic this setup in another workspace but didn't have the same problem.

Turns out to be a dup of bug 166976. John A tested the fix to bug 166976 to verify.

This problem occurrs when one JRE is bound to more than one execution environment. The access rules computed for the first environment a JRE is bound to were incorrectly re-used on the next EE. 

*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of bug 166976 ***
